Ann Arbor Public Schools Records, 1833-2011
titlepage.author:
Finding aid created by Mary Kenney, May 2005,
Additional accession processed by Rachel Powers, September 2013

did.abstract: The records of the Ann Arbor Public Schools, cover the numerous districts and schools that developed and then gradually merged into an area school system which today encompasses twenty-one elementary schools, five middle schools, and three high schools with a school population of 16,724 (as of May 17, 2005).

repository.corpname: Bentley Historical Library, University of Michigan

acqinfo.p: The record group was received from Ann Arbor Public Schools (donor no. 6063) in multiple accessions.

accessrestrict.p: The record group is open to research.

userestrict.p: Copyright is held by the Regents of the University of Michigan.

prefercite.p: [item], folder, box, Ann Arbor Public Schools Records, Bentley Historical Library, University of Michigan

bioghist.p: The first 'school' in Washtenaw County was an outdoor school held in the summer of 1825 near Platt Road, eventually replaced by a log cabin. In 1837 another log cabin school was erected in Pittsfield Township, at which site in 1953 would be built Meadowview School. The development of the schools in Pittsfield Township is well-documented in this collection, in the Pittsfield Township, 1833-1960 series.

Historically, schools grew from small population centers and then gradually merged and coalesced into larger systems. Small settlements grew into villages then to townships. There were annexations by Ann Arbor which brought rural school districts into the urban system. Events affecting population movements, such as World War I and World War II, impacted school development. State legislation would address the educational needs of growing areas as the demands for education grew over the decades.
The Ann Arbor Board of Education has almost continuous documentation through meeting minutes and Board agendas which reflect the organizational activities of the administration.

Researchers will notice that documentation is sometimes scattered and with gaps, but there is sufficient evidence of major events such as desegregation of the Ann Arbor Public Schools in the 1960's that gives a good picture of the times. Scrapbooks form a large part of the collection for the twentieth century for the period of 1933-1969. Clippings highlight not only school events and achievements, but also the events in the larger community that impact school policy.

Related collections are: Ann Arbor Public Schools Faculty Wives and Otto W. Haisley, who was superintendent in the 1920's. Researchers may also consult the Ann Arbor, Michigan photographic collection for photographs of schools. Pittsfield (Washtenaw County, Mich.) is a related collection that contains the earliest School district records for Pittsfield Township as held by the county, such as school census and annual reports, directors reports, and inspector's reports. A resource created in 2003, the Brown v. the Board of Education Archive, highlights desegregation in the Ann Arbor Schools and the Jones School closing. As of 2013 the link for this digital exhibit is: http://www.lib.umich.edu/brown-versus-board-education/. A History of Desegregation of the Ann Arbor Public Schools, 1954-1976 by Mary Jo Frank is available online (as of 2013) at http://name.umdl.umich.edu/AUS0335.0001.001

scopecontent.p: The collection consists of nine series: Ann Arbor Board of Education, 1838-1994; Ann Arbor Public Schools Historic Records, 1853-1970; Historic School District Records, 1865-1965; Pittsfield Township, 1833-1960; Administration, 1946-1982; Desegregation, 1965-1970; Scrapbooks, 1933-1969; Miscellaneous other records; 2012 Accession.
Ann Arbor Board of Education, 1857-2011 (AAPS) series includes agenda items for Board meetings, minutes, rules, a partial index to Board proceedings, and audio tapes with historical narratives.

The 2012 Accession includes files on facility planning (2000-2004), bond/sinking fund (2004), new school (1998-2005), and miscellaneous topics notably a set of school dedication and anniversary programs and a series of three volumes containing students' writings in the early 1940s, mainly autobiographical and some relating to World War II experiences, by fifth graders at Angell, Eberbach, and an unidentified school.

scopecontent.p: Ann Arbor Public Schools Historic Records, 1853-1970 series contains a wide range of documents and volumes covering administration, school elections, statistics from Ann Arbor schools primarily in the early history of the system. The content of the series is scattered, but has many unique historic notebooks and records that give a view into the operations of the original system and how it evolved.

scopecontent.p: Historic School District Records, 1865-1977 series contains documents, mainly meeting minutes, for school districts and for some individual schools with no particular rationale of content. The term "district" seems to have different definitions for different historic periods.

did.unittitle: Director's Book of Records and Accounts
Director's Book of Records and Accounts
District No. 16 fractional, Ann Arbor and Scio Townships
Glacier Way-Green Road Elementary, Proposed Educational Specifications

scopecontent.p: Pittsfield Township, 1833-1960 series contains the earliest records of this collection. Annual reports, teacher term reports, teacher contracts, financial reports, and meeting minutes together form a detailed picture of the functioning of the early Ann Arbor schools before separate districts merged.

did.unittitle: Pittsfield Village and Platt Road School
Sale of community school property by Pittsfield District
Martha D. Mitchell Elementary School addition

scopecontent.p: Administration, 1946-1982 series includes a wide range of organizational information on the post-war, modern school system in Ann Arbor. The series is divided into time periods that coincide with the records. The period 1968-1970 was well documented through the inclusion of the records of the superintendent, Scott Westerman, whose working files are made available here. The purchase and sale of properties and construction of new schools are documented as well as studies and reports on projects.

scopecontent.p: Desegregation, 1965-1970 series documents the Jones School Study and efforts of the AAPS to create a more fair racial balance in the schools. Scrapbooks of clippings of that period are arranged chronologically and well-labeled.

did.unittitle: Jones School Study Rating Scales and Test Instruments
Jones School Reassignment Project Master File
Requests for the study and other documentation
Ann Arbor Board of Education presentations
Dr. Carrigan, Office of Research presentation text

scopecontent.p: Scrapbooks, 1933-1969 series contains a wide range of clippings about many aspects of the AAPS as portrayed in the local papers.

The Miscellaneous other records series contains documentation of Ann Arbor High School alumni activities. Also of interest are minutes of meetings of the school's teachers, 1906-1922, and of the Board in Control of Non-Athletic Organizations, 1904-1938.
